El préstamo solicitado es para la compra de materiales para su olería.

loans.use: purchase of cement, sand and other supplies

loans.name: Silvia Elena

texts.es:
For 2 years, Silvia has operated a shop selling general merchandise in the Santa Ana market in Nicaragua's "departamento" of Chinandega. She's married with two school-age children. They're the reason that she works so hard, earning money to support the household, determined that they need not depend solely on the small earnings of their father.

For the past year, Silvia has borrowed funds from Ceprodel to buy merchandise such as cooking oil, soap, detergent, snacks, bread, etc. In short, all of the products that she offers in her shop. Today, once again, she needs to invest in her business by purchasing merchandise for resale and she's applying to Ceprodel for a loan, knowing that they won't fail her. Her record is 6 loans from the lender.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Desde hace 2 años atrás, la señora Silvia S. se dedica al negocio de pulpería en el mercado Santa Ana del departamento de Chinandega. Es madre casada y con dos hijos en edad escolar. Por tal motivo es que ella se esfuerza grandemente por llevar el sustento a su hogar y que sus hijos no solamente dependan de los bajos ingresos de su padre sino también de ella como madre.

Desde hace un año atrás, la señora Silvia ha realizado créditos con Ceprodel de los cuales los ha utilizado para la compra de los productos tales como aceite, jabón, detergente, galletas, pan, etc. En fin todos los productos ofrecidos en la pulpería. Hoy en día una ves mas necesita la inversión en su negocio para la adquisición de estos productos y para ello es que solicita crédito en CEPRODEL sabiendo que no le fallará. Su record es de 6 créditos con esta institución.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Mrs Suon S., 47, is married with eight children and works as a housewife looking after the children and cooking food for her family members. Her husband, Mr. Sok Chunly, 58, works as a construction worker in his village, which normally earns him $2.90 a day. Three of their daughters are employed as garment workers in Phnom Penh city, earning a salary of $60 each a month, while four others are students. This couple aims to use their loan from Kiva to buy sand, iron, and cement to renovate the house.

loans.use: To purchase sand, iron and cement to revovate the house.

loans.name: Vladislav

texts.en:
Vladislav is a sharp young entrepreneur from Zaporozhye, Ukraine. He owns a small business making duplicate keys. Vladislav started his business about five years ago with just one location. Since then, he has opened two additional kiosks and has hired employees to work for him. Each of his business places are in locations with good visibility, convenient access, and plenty of passing customer traffic, all of which helps to ensure stable demand and profits. Vladislav makes around $700 per month from his business.

Vladislav has requested a loan of $1000 to increase his available working capital. He has proven to be a reliable, goal-oriented business owner and has established a good relationship with Nadiya Ukraine. We are happy to be able to further assist him with operating a successful, profitable business.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate A. is fifty-two years old. She is married with eight children. Three of the children are currently in school. She has been selling smoked fish for the past fourteen years. Kate believes in hard work and dedication. She has been financing her children’s educations with income from her business. She deems it an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use the loan to buy more boxes of fish to increase sales and income. She belongs to the community group called Adoration Trust Group. The group agrees in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 31-year-old Grace K.. She is married and has 2 children, ages 5 and 9. She has 1 dependent. In 2005 Grace established her seamstress business. Grace requires a loan in order to purchase a sewing machine. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia is a member of the "Las Flores" community bank. She lives in the Peruvian "region" of San Martin and operates a general store, selling a variety of products from her shop. Thanks to her perseverance, with the support of her husband and children, Lucia has managed to grow the business significantly and she now has a well-stocked store offering a range of products to customers who come to her day after day.

With the S/.700 (700 Peruvian soles), to be repaid in 4 months, Lucia will buy pastas of various kinds and brands; boxes of canned foods; sacks of rice and sugar; cooking oil in liter bottles; bulk supplies of eggs, "menestras" (a local soup) and different kinds of fruit from the coast, all things that her customers demand.

Lucia, 38, lives with her husband and their 4 children. She feels free to make decisions for her business and manage it the way that she wants. Her charisma draws her customers in as surely as her well-stocked store.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Lucia R. C., es socia del Banco Comunal Las “Flores “ vive en la región de San Martín, provincia de Rioja, distrito de Rioja, se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general y granos, su local cuenta con una variedad de producto, está ubicado en el Mercado Faustino Maldonado puesto 20 del mismo distrito. Gracias a su perseverancia en el trabajo, el apoyo de su esposo e hijos, ha logrado que el negocio se incremente considerablemente actualmente cuenta con un negocio bien surtido, oferta variedad de productos, a sus clientes que a diario le visitan.

El préstamo recibido de S/. 700.00 que será devuelto en 4 meses, con dicho capital comprará fideos de distintas variedades y marcas en paquetes, conservas en cajas, arroz y azúcar en sacos, aceite en botellas de litro, huevos en javas, menestras y una variedad de frutas de la costa debido a que estos alimentos son muy requeridos por sus clientes .

Tiene 38 años, vive con su esposo y sus 4 hijos de edad, se considera independiente para decidir y manejar su negocio. Por su carisma atrae a sus clientes además de atenderlas con amabilidad y tener un negocio surtido.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Martha's Hekima Group

texts.en:
Martha is a married woman with 7 children between 10 and 36. She also takes care of 2 other children aged 6 and 4 years old. She became a maize and milk seller in 1998. Every day, she works from 7:30am to 6:30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Martha now hopes for a loan to buy more maize and milk for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with banana sales, beans, and maize sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Charles A.b.

texts.en:
This is Charles A.B. F.. He is a businessman in Makeni City. He has been selling ready-to-wear-clothes for the past 8 years now. Charles is 34 years old, married with 2 children.

Charles is requesting a loan of Le 3,000,000.00. This will be his first loan from Kiva through SMT. With this loan, Charles will buy more clothes, shoes and jewelry to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy clothes, etc. to add to his business inventory

loans.name: Novruz

texts.en:
Novruz S. is a 61-year-old farmer, married with two grown sons. For thirteen years he has raised sheep. He has very strong health that's allow him to pasture his sheep. His two sons help him by selling sheep once a week in the local bazaar. He is still is very poor and lives in very hard conditions.

He would like to expand his business and purchase 15 sheep for 60 USD each, and fodder. He also wants to improve the winter conditions for sheep. He wishes to improve his life so that one day he could have a big herd of sheep.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and fodder

loans.name: Christine Nalubega's Group

texts.en:
Christine is the leader of a group of 5 members. She is 36 years old and married with 6 children, aged between 18 years and 4 months. Four of her children go to school. She resides in a one-roomed house, where she is staying with eight people. Christine takes care of three orphans: her late brother's children. They have electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets two meals a day. They rarely take tea.

She resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Christine sells food products like cassava, sweet and Irish potatoes in Kawaala market near her home. She doesn't incur any transport costs because she buys from her place of work. She can sell to an average of 15 customers a day and sells to all categories of people. Her monthly expenses include rent for the business and home, food and school fees for the orphans. Christine works seven days a week.

Christine has been with MCDT for four years, working with the same groupmates. She is servicing her eighth loan and is aspiring to see her business expand so that she can start going to the villages to get stocks herself.

loans.use: To boost her food product business

loans.name: Oisifat

texts.ru: Наимова Ойсифат проживает в городе ТУрсун-Заде. Возраст 46 лет. Замужем и имеет шестерых детей. Работает на рынке "Дехкон" города ТУрсун-Заде. Имеет торговую точку , где продает различные промышленные и бытовые товары. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 8 лет. В данный момент планирует увеличить товарооборот , путем получения кредита. Это поможет развивать деятельность , которая приносит ей неплохой доход.Погасить кредит сможет в течение 4 месяцев.
texts.en:
Oisifat N. lives in the city Tursun-zoda. She is 46, married, and has six children. She works in the Dehkon market in Tursun-zoda. She has a shop where she sells various industrial and household goods. She has been doing this work for eight years. Now, she would like to increase sales by taking out a loan. It will help her develop her business, which brings in a comfortable income. She can pay off the loan in four months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen Osemwenyaru makes a living as a caterer. She bakes egg rolls, meat pies and many other delicacies. She is also involved in outdoor catering for marriages, burials and other events. She is applying for this loan to buy a refrigerator, an oven and bags of flour. She says thank you to everyone who makes this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator, an oven and bags of flour

loans.name: Rim

texts.en:
Mrs. Rim K. is 50 years old, and now lives in Kanthorm village in Kampong Speu province with her husband and two children. Her children are employed in a garment factory. She has a plot of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Suk San, is a construction worker.

Even though Mrs. Rim K. and her husband try to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support the family. In order to provide better living conditions, Mrs. Rim K. is requesting a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business.

loans.use: Buy a cow to start a breeding business to improve living conditions

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Pheap K. is 38 years old and is the mother of three children attending local school. Her husband, Mr. Chiem Van is on the right in the photo. They live in Prey Me Long Thboung village in the Takeo province.

Mrs. Pheap K. and her husband are farmers who own a piece of land and cultivate rice. On this plantation, they earn very little income to support their family living.

Mr. Chiem Van would like to buy raw material to make candies to start a new business. Mrs. Pheap K. is requesting a loan for this purpose. They hope to increase their income and improve their living conditions with the help of this loan.

loans.use: To buy raw material to make candies to start a new business.

loans.name: Amistad Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Amistad inicia su tercer ciclo con  20 socias.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de quesos, calzados, abarrotes, ropa, animales menores, leña, elaboración de jugos y farmacia.

Como es el caso de Primitiva que es conviviente, tiene 39 años y 5 hijos, Primitiva vende quesos de manera ambulatoria que compra en las ferias.

Por otro lado Elsa es separada, tiene 44 años y 3 hijos, Elsa vende calzados variados en la feria dominical de San Juan, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Lima.

Mientras que Edna que es conviviente, tiene 40 años y 2 hijos, Edna tiene un puesto en el mercado Nery García en donde vende abarrotes, actividad que realiza todos los días.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, 1000soles, 900 soles  haciendo un total de 14,100 soles de prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra de queso, arroz, azúcar, zapatos escolares, chompas, pantalones, leña, medicinas, carnes, animales.

Los sueños de las socias son aumentar sus negocios, que sus hijos salgan adelante y sean profesionales, tener los ahorros suficiente para la vejez y progresar.
texts.en:
The Amistad Communal Bank began its third cycle with 20 members. The members have different businesses such as selling cheese, shoes, groceries, clothing, small animals, firewood, production of juices and pharmacology. As is the case with Primativa who is married, is 39 years old and has 5 children, Primitiva sells cheese that she buys in the market from a moving cart. On the other hand Elsa is separated, 44 years old and has 3 children; Elsa sells various kinds of footwear at the Sunday market in San Juan, she acquires her products in the city of Lima. Edna is married, is 40 years old and has 2 children, Edna has a spot in the Nery García market where she sells groceries, an activity that she does every day. The members need different loan amounts as 300 soles, 600 soles, 1000 soles, 900 soles for a total of 14,100 soles in loans from Banco Comunal. Their loans will be invested in the purchase of cheese, rice, sugar, shoes, school supplies, sweaters, pants, firewood, medicines, meat, animals. The dreams of the members are to increase their business, that their children succeed and become professionals, and to have enough savings for old age and to progress.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Their loans will be invested in the purchase of cheese, rice, sugar, shoes, school supplies, sweaters, pants, firewood, medicines, meat, animals.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
JULIA CÁRDENAS P., pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Fortaleza” su casa se ubica en el Jr. Unión N° 401 del Distrito de Callería, tiene 38 años, 04 hijos que aun continúan estudiando a excepción del primero, su esposo se dedica al comercio de madera.

	El primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos fue de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, con el que inicio su negocio de abarrotes, no fue mucho, pero si lo necesario para comprar un poco de verduras y algunos abarrotes.

El préstamo de S/.1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, con ello comprará productos para sus abarrotes todo al por mayor, arroz, azúcar, fideo, aceite y todo lo necesario para que su negocio se vea completo. 

Agradece a Manuela Ramos por su facilidad con los préstamos, y haberle dado la oportunidad para surgir y salir adelante.
texts.en:
JULIA CÁRDENAS P., 38, is a member of the communal bank “La Fortaleza” ("The Fortress"). She lives in the Callería district with her husband, who sells wood. They have four children; three still live at home and go to school. Julia's first loan (300 soles) was used to start a small grocery store. It was not much, but she was able to buy basic products and vegetables to sell. She is now requesting a loan of 1,000 soles, to purchase wholesale products like rice, sugar, pasta, oil, and others. Julia is thankful to Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for providing easy access to credit and for giving her the opportunity to have a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing wholesale rice, sugar, pasta, oil, etc. to stock grocery store

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Ana de 44 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive con una de sus 3 hijas. Se dedica a la costura desde hace 2 años atrás, a razón de haber aprendido empíricamente cuando le apoyaba a su madre, quien era una de las mejores costureras en sus tiempos. Ana solo cose ropa para damas y niños, y esta labor la realiza en las instalaciones de su casa, contando con el apoyo de su hija, quien se encarga de hacer los cortes de las telas. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es dar lo mejor de ella para que sus clientes se sientan satisfechos, y le es rentable porque aparte de brindar sus servicios de costura a personas particulares, también confecciona ropa para llevar a vender. La señora Ana es muy activa puesto que también vende productos de belleza por catálogo y le va muy bien. Al momento tiene 2 préstamos con MFP, en estos tiempos están habiendo problemas en su banco comunal porque algunos de sus integrante no asisten a las reuniones, pero Ana se mantiene firme en su responsabilidad con sus pagos. Invertirá la cantidad que solicita en la compra de materiales de costura y productos de belleza.
texts.en:
Ana is 44 years old, is a single mother and lives with her 3 daughters. She has been a seamstress for the past 2 years, which she had learned empirically when she was supporting her mother, who was one of the best seamstresses of her time. Ana only sews clothing for women and children. She has set up her work in an installation of her house, counting on the support of her daughter, who is in charge of making the cuts of fabric.

What she likes about her work is giving the best of herself so that her customers feel satisfied. It is profitable to her because, apart from providing her sewing services to particular people, she also makes clothing to sell. Miss Ana is very active given that she also sells beauty products for catalogs, which is going very well for her.

At the moment, she has 2 loans with MFP. At this time they are having problems within the communal bank because some of its members don’t attend the meetings, but Ana remains firm in her responsibility with her payments. She will invest the amount she is requesting in the purchase of sewing materials and beauty products.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Sattin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing sewing materials and beauty products

loans.name: Faava

texts.en:
Faava T., 31, is married with three children. She has one year of experience in the vegetables garden business. She sells to the general public seven days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (approximately $240).

She has no previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Faava’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase barbed wire, seeds and chemical spray

loans.name: Vitaliana

texts.es: Vitaliana es una mujer de 47 años, actualmente está separada de su pareja y asume las responsabilidades de sus dos hijos con quienes vive en la casa que construyó con su esfuerzo de largos años. A pesar de las dificultades, no deja de trabajar en diversos oficios, pero en la actividad que más está involucrada es en la venta de cosméticos, pues sus 10 años de experiencia le ayudaron a captar clientes fieles que realizan quincenalmente sus pedidos. La meta de Vitaliana es de  incrementar sus pedidos y ganar los premios que realiza la empresa a las mujeres con mayor cantidad de ventas, pues así las motivan a seguir creciendo. Para esto, ha instalado un puesto en su casa donde ofrece sus productos y puede dejar de caminar de casa en casa, y de exponerse a los cambios de clima. Vitaliana es fundadora de su grupo, se encuentra en su quinceavo crédito con MFP y espera seguir trabajando junto a sus compañeras que han sabido ser responsables y colaboradoras. Con el dinero solicitado comprará productos al por mayor, pues como promotora tiene la oportunidad de adquirir productos a costos módicos y en mayores cantidades.
texts.en:
Vitaliana is a 47-year-old woman who is currently separated and has custody of her two children. She and her children live together in the house that she built after many long years of struggle. Despite the difficulties, she does not stop working various jobs, but the one that she is most involved in is cosmetics sales. Her 10 years of experience have helped her gain loyal customers who order from her on a bi-weekly basis. Vitalina’s goal is to increase her orders so that she can win prizes that the company gives out to the women with the highest sales, thus motivating them to keep growing as entrepreneurs. For this, she has set up a stand in her house to offer products, that way, she no longer has to walk door-to-door and expose herself to harsh weather conditions. Vitalina is the founder of her group. She is currently in her fifth loan from MFP, and she hopes to keep working alongside her group members, who have worked together responsibly. With the money that she is requesting, she will purchase wholesale products because as a promoter, she has the chance of obtaining a greater quantity of products at a reasonable price.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing goods

loans.name: Agustina

texts.es:
La señora Agustina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Semillas del Futuro” el cual esta ubicado en el distrito de Puno, Provincia de  Puno, Departamento de Puno. Tiene 54 años, es madre soltera y tiene 05 hijos (solo dos a su cargo) presenta estudios de secundaria completa y vive en el Barrio Huajsapata.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace casi 2 años, con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 para su negocio de compra y venta de frutas. 

Actualmente solicita un préstamo de S/. 800.00 para poder invertir en su actual negocio y así poder comprar mas productos como: naranjas, plátanos, papayas, mandarinas, uvas y otros.

A ella le gustan las facilidades de pago y las reuniones de su Banco Comunal. Su mayor sueño es poner una tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Augustina belongs to the Semillas del Futuro (Seeds of the Future) Communal Bank, which is located in the Puno District, Puno Province. She is a 54 year old single mother of five (only two of whom are still at home) who completed her high school education and lives in Huajsapata area. She has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for nearly two years, investing an initial loan of 300 PEN into her fruit and vegetable business. She is currently seeking a loan of 800 PEN to invest in buying more produce for her business, such as oranges, bananas, papayas, mandarins, grapes etc. She likes her Communal Bank's easy payment terms and meetings. Her greatest aspiration is to open a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Stilgoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruits such as oranges, bananas, papayas, mandarins, grapes etc.

loans.name: Dare

texts.en: T. is 49 years old. She is a widow with two children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. T. has a place where she sells drinks, paper soup (an appetizer made from goat meat), goat meat and recharge cards. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more drinks, foodstuffs and recharge cards. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, foodstuffs and recharge cards to sell

loans.name: Las Hormiguitas Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Hormiguitas es parte del proyecto Wari, El Banco Comunal inicia su Tercer ciclo con 10 socias. Las socias son de la comunidad de Rumichaca, distrito de Pillpichaca, Provincia de Huaytara, Departamento de Huancavelica. Las actividades principales son la crianza de animales como la alpaca, llama, ovino y actividades de comercio por estar ubicada en la Vía Libertadores – Wari.
	
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de golosinas, ropa, jugos, comidas, joyas, pesado, abarrotes y servicio de hospedaje.

Como es el caso de Lourdes que es casada, tiene 4 hijos, es presidenta del Banco Comunal, Lourdes vende comida, bebidas, golosinas en el puesto de Rumichaka, Además Lourdes tiene un pequeño alojamiento.

Mientras que Mónica es madre soltera, tiene 3 hijos, Mónica tiene un cafetín en donde vende bebidas, golosinas, además trabaja como cocinera en una institución. 

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 200 soles, 600 soles, 1000 soles, haciendo un total de 6,700 soles de prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra de galletas, chicles, gaseosas, arroz, azucar, leche, aceite.

Los sueños de las socias son mejorar su casa, tener casa propia, sus hijos sean profesionales, mejorar sus negocios.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Hormiguitas" is part of the Wari project. The bank is beginning its 3rd cycle with 10 members. The members come from the Rumichaca community, Pillpichaca district, in the Huaytara Province of the Huancavelica Department. The principal activities are raising animals, such as llamas and sheep, and conducting commercial business in Via Libertadores - Wari. The members each conduct different business, such as hospitality, and selling sweets, clothes, juice, jewelry, fish, and groceries. Such is the case of Lourdes, who is married with 4 children. Lourdes is the president of the communal bank, and sells food, drinks, and sweets at a post in Rumichaka. On the other hand, Monica is a single mother with 3 children. She has a small cafeteria where she sells drinks and sweets. She also works as a cook at an institution. The members need different loan amounts. Their loans will be invested in the purchase of crackers, gum, soft drinks, rice, sugar, milk, and oil. The members' dreams are to improve their houses, or buy their own house, help their children become professional, and improve their own businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase crackers, gum, soft drinks, rice, sugar, milk, and oil

loans.name: Doki

texts.fr: Doki A. est une jeune femme de  28 ans. Elle est domiciliée à Lomé, dans le quartier Dzidzolé. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants.  Elle est une petite commerçante des sacs de friperies juste à côté du Commissariat de Dzidzolé. Ce crédit lui permettra de faire des achats des sacs en ballots, ce qui lui permettra de maximiser énormément son bénéfice, et par conséquent, d'assumer le bien-être de sa famille.
texts.en:
Doki A. is a young woman of 28. She lives in Lomé, in the Dzidzolé neighborhood. She is married and the mother of 2 children. She is a petty trader who sells used handbags right beside the Commissariat in Dzidzolé. This loan will allow her to buy used bags in bales, which will help enormously in maximizing her profit, and thus will allow her to be responsible for the well-being of her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying used bags wholesale

loans.name: Khyorng

texts.en: T., who is thirty-five years old, is the mother of six children, one of whom is married and lives separately. The other five are single, some working and some still in school. T.'s income is derived from her farming and the help of her working children. She wants to invest in her farm, so she decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer for her fields. She wants her children to finish their schooling.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farming.

loans.name: Anara's Group

texts.en:
Anara, 34, is a housewife. Her husband earns his family’s living by working as a driver, transporting various goods. Their three children go to school (her eldest son is graduating this year). Following their neighbors’ advice, they started keeping cattle. For now, Anara keeps two cows and sells the milk. Selling milk brings in around $50 a month, which constitutes a considerable contribution to the family budget. Without this income, it would take Anara’s husband much longer to buy a truck. Anara and her husband need a loan to buy spares for the truck in order to start providing conveyance services. In the near future, they plan to buy a house in the city of Tokmok.

Anara is the leader of this group. Here are Anara’s partners: Janyl, Amantur and Tumara. They live in a rural area and enjoy they lives. They represent hardworking middle income families, whose enjoyment of life springs from its very simplicity and their way of living.

Janyl, 48, is married. She is the mother of five children. Most of her children are grown-ups and live away from home. Her husband works as a builder. Janyl is a housewife. She keeps cows and sells nine liters of milk per day. Janyl needs a loan to buy one more cow. She wants to save money from selling milk to pay for one of her daughter’s college education.

Amantur, 24, is married. He drives a tractor and earns his living by offering transportation services. Amantur would like to obtain a loan to purchase some cattle. His dream is to build a big house in his village.

Tumara, 38, is married. She is raising four children, the eldest of whom is seven. Her husband works as an electrician, whereas she stays at home and sells milk. Her independent earnings have let her buy some furniture for the house. Tumara needs a loan to buy a stallion.

======================================
Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3 P's concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to further your support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy spares for the truck to start providing conveyance services

loans.name: Elgiba

texts.es: Elgiba es  una persona dinámica y colaborador, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa provincia de Coronel Portillo, tiene 58 años y es madre de seis hijos todos mayores de edad, se dedica a la venta de gaseosas en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo. Es socia del Banco Comunal  “Bellavista” desde hace seis años. Su primer préstamo fue de 300 soles que invirtió en gaseosa, en la actualidad necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles que será invertido en la compra de madera, negocio en el que está incursionando. La meta de Elgiba es tener capital para ser mayorista en gaseosa.

loans.use: Invertirá en la compra de madera.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita B. is from the village of P-2, Tag-ibo, Iligan City. She is 38 years old. Angelita is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Angelita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop selling products in the local community like basic needs items, snacks and others. Angelita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Angelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Angelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: P-2, Tag-ibo, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace R. is from the village of San Carlos,Tukuran Zamoanga Del Sur. She is 24 years old. Mary Grace is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Grace owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and meals in the local community. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Mary Grace joined GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mary Grace from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Ha Ut Group

texts.en: Mrs. Ha U. is a group leader of four and they all live in Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province. Mrs. Ha U. is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Soy Roem, is a construction worker. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still don't earn enough income to support the family's living. In order to improve the family's living, Mrs. Ha U. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She is 24 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because this child is only one year old.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Jawhara

texts.en: Jawhara is a 28-year-old married woman and mother of 2 young children. She has been working as a home-based tailor since 2006 and has 8 years of experience in this field. She is requesting a loan of US$ 1,200 to buy a new sewing machine to be able to make more products for her clients.

loans.use: buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Yalda

texts.en: Yalda, daughter of A. G., is 38 years old and married with two children. She operates a tailoring business from home with most of her clients being neighbors. She would like to take an individual loan of 14700 Afghani to buy sewing materials and a new sewing machine. Her old machine doesn’t work properly and she encounters many problems while sewing. She is confident she will repay her loan on time and thanks Kiva lenders for their support to entrepreneurs around Afghanistan.

loans.use: To purchase a new machine

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene S. lives in Labo, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old, is married, and is the mother of two children, one of whom is shown with her in the photo.

Eugene owns and operates a sari-sari (general) store. She has been engaged in this kind of business and earns approximately Php 2,000 a month.

In 2006, Eugene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of Php 7,000 from PMPC.

Eugene is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional items for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase and sale of cooking utensils

loans.name: Mujeres Activas Group

texts.es:
Para la formación el presente comité inicio la Señora Lilian A. Integrante del comité “Mujeres Activas”,   domiciliada en el km 10 Acaray   de Ciudad del Este. Ella Contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formaron nuevo  comité en la Zona.
El comité se Denomina “Mujeres Activas”  están  en el Segundo Ciclo   con 16  integrantes , es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas, solidarias  y responsables realizan labores para la comunidad y el comité ,  ellas tienen actividades diferentes e independientes además de algunos trabajos en grupo que lo realizan para juntar fondos para el comité para cualquier necesidad o urgencia de alguna integrante.
La señora Claudelina es una de las integrantes del comité y ella opto por la actividad de abrir un pequeño negocio con todo los productos de la canasta básica familiar, poco a poco fue creciendo el negocio y actualmente ya cuenta con mercaderías en mayor cantidad.
El marido de la señora Claudelina es albañil y procura juntos por día a día de su familia queriendo dar un mejor futuro para sus hijos.
Asi todas las integrante tienen una experiencia de vida que contar , seguido se citan las actividades que realizan las demás integrantes.

texts.en:
This committee known as “Mujeres Activas” (Active Women) was started in the home of Sra. Lilian A. which is located at km 10 Acaray in Ciudad del Este. Lilian contacted her friends and neighbors to form a new committee in this region.

“Mujeres Activas” is starting its second loan cycle with 16 members. The group is known for being close-knit, supportive, and responsible in carrying out its work in the community and within the committee. They have business activities and also work independently. As a group, they work together to raise the funds necessary to meet the needs or emergencies of any member.

Sra. Claudelina is one of the committee members and has decided to open a small business that carries all the products needed for the family dinner table. Over time she has increased her business and is currently stocked with a large quantity of merchandise. Her husband works as a mason, and together, they work to provide their children a better future.

All of the members have their own life experiences that they can recount. The business activities for each of the members are cited below:

1. Claudelina A. – Dispensary 2. Nidia A. – Dispensary 3. Silvia R. – Linen sales 4. Gladys González – Clothing sales 5. Ilda L. – Clothing sales 6. Vilma V. – Dispensary 7. Josefa Fernández – Laundry 8. Damacia O. – Food sales 9. Maria Álvarez – Poultry sales 10. Mercedes V. – Handicrafts 11. María O. – Undergarment sales 12. Ramona Fernández – Used clothing sales 13. Diana C. – Clothing sales 14. Emilia B. – Dispensary 15. Rosa A. – Poultry sales 16. Delia A. – Beauty salon

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for their respective businesses

loans.name: Elva

texts.es:
Elva es una emprendedora mujer de 34 años, vive al lado de su esposo y sus hijos de 16, 15 y 14 años. Todos ellos viven en su casa propia.

Desde hace 2 años se dedica a la venta de zapatos, actualmente está vendiendo sandalias, ya que el verano amerita el uso de este calzado, es por ello que viene teniendo buenas ventas. Elva compra las sandalias por docenas y en variedad de diseños, para que cuando las ofrezca tenga diversidad para sus clientes. Todo este tiempo, su trabajo ha hecho que se sienta independiente y con mucha fortaleza para seguir mejorando su negocio, es así que quisiera tener un puesto fijo en una zona muy concurrida para vender con mayor comodidad sus zapatos.

Este es su primer crédito con MFP y su grupo denominado “Mujeres Triunfadoras de Ventanilla” es muy unido y responsable, por lo cual cree que no tendrá problemas con los pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mayor cantidad de sandalias para aumentar sus ventas en esta época veraniega.
texts.en:
Elva, 34, is an enterprising woman; she lives in her own house with her husband and their children, who are 16, 15 and 14 years of age. For the last 2 years she has sold shoes, even selling sandals, because Summer calls for this type of footwear. This is why her sales have been good. Elva buys sandals by the dozen in an assortment of styles so that when she puts them on display there is much diversity for her customers. All this time, her work has made it possible for her to feel independent and strong in order to continue improving her business. She wants to have a fixed locale in a busy part of town to sell her shoes in more comfortably. This is her first loan with MFP and her communal bank called, "Mujeres Triunfadoras de Ventanilla" (Winning Women from Ventanilla). It is a very unified and responsible group so she does not anticipate any problems with repayments. She will use the funds to buy larger amounts of sandals to increase sales during Summer season.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sandals.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sell food products

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Âgée de 34 ans et mère d’un enfant, Madame Salimata D. (en instance de divorce avec son mari) vit  chez ses parents dans le quartier Kouloukoro de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance de continuer les études primaires, Salimata n’a pas pris du temps à s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman depuis son jeune âge et l’exerce pour elle-même depuis maintenant 11 ans. Son activité principale est la vente des bijoux, chaussures, pagnes et autres articles divers. Elle est très sollicitée et appréciée par les femmes de la ville de Koutiala. 
Afin d’augmenter son fonds de commerce  et satisfaire sa clientèle en qualité, Madame Salimata décida de rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso en  2007. Après  2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement, elle est à son 2ème  prêt  individuel dont le premier fut également correctement remboursé.  
Avec ce financement elle compte acheter, une quantité importante de colliers et 20 paires de chaussures. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et souvent au Sénégal  et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle composée  de jeunes filles et de femmes mariées  au comptant et à  crédit.  
Elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement du prêt   de Soro Yiriwaso,  satisfaire ses besoins, entretenir son enfant  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Age 34 and mother of one child, Mrs. Salimata D. (in the process of divorcing her husband) lives with her parents in the Kouloukoro quarter of Koutiala city (3rd region of Mali). Never having had the chance to finish elementary school, Salimata did not have time to take an interest in work except for her mother's business. She has now done the same work for 11 years. Her main business is the purchase of jewelry, shoes, fabrics, and other various items. She is often solicited for her business and appreciated by the women of Koutiala. In order to increase her commercial funds and satisfy her customers with quality work, Mrs. Salimata decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in 2007. After two group loans which are repaid, she is on her second individual loan. The first was repaid in full. With this loan, she counts on purchasing a large quantity of necklaces and 20 pairs of shoes. She gets her stock in Bamako and often in Sénégal. She makes her sales in the city of Koutiala to young girls and married women. Sales are made in both cash and credit. She plans on making a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA which she will use to repay the loan from Soro Yiriwaso, meet her needs, support her child, and invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of necklaces and shoes

loans.name: Daniel Lelei

texts.en:
Daniel Lelei M. is a gentleman who is 35 years old. He is married to Priscilla M. and together, they have five beautiful children. They live in Sinonin in Eldoret, where their farm is. Daniel is a maize farmer who sells maize mostly to his neighbors soon after harvest. He has been farming for 10 years now and this has enabled him to feed, clothe and provide shelter for his family since his wife is a housewife.

Daniel was introduced to KADET by a KADET client and this will be his first loan with KADET, a Kiva partner. He is planning to use the entire loan on his farm by buying three bags of fertilizer worth 7,500 Kenyan shillings and maize seedlings worth Kshs 2,750. He will use the rest for plowing.

Daniel is also a mason in addition to farming. His dream is to improve in farming and also own more land so he can get more income to feed, clothe and provide shelter for his family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and maize seedlings

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: K. Paul is thirty-five years old and married with five children. He owns a clinic (Hope Medical Centre) on Zirridamu Street, in Kalisizo sub-county, Kyotera county, Rakai district. His clinic provides admission for patients. He is using the loan to purchase clinical equipment and machines. He is a very hardworking businessman whose future aspirations are to expand the clinic and build a better and more convenient place for patients. He also wants to make sure all his children are educated.

loans.use: To purchase clinical equipment and machines

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda D. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Erlinda is married and has 4 school-aged children. She makes and sells snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Erlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Erlinda is requesting her second loan, for 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more produce like maize and cassava to sell

loans.name: Zandra

texts.en:
Zandra L. is from the village of Paradise, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 44 years old. Zandra is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Zandra operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing, like skirts, t-shirts and blouses, in the local community. Zandra has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Zandra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Zandra is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Zandra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Genoviva

texts.en:
Genoviva A. is a 46-year-old married woman who lives in Narcery, Brgy. East, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store.

Genoviva’s husband Lorito is a driver and they have five children who are between 9 and 23 years old.  Two of their children are currently going to school and help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Genoviva joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000 from her business activities.

Genoviva is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 was used to fund operations of her general store and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her eighth loan in the amount of PHP 15,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital for her general store. She is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Godwinodhiambo

texts.en: Godwin Odhiambo O. is 29 year old and lives in Kisumu. He operates a poultry business in Jubilee market which he started in 2000. Initially he was employed but the salary could not adequately meet the rising needs of his family. He travels to Ahero and Sondu markets to enable him meet the ever increasing demand for poultry in Kisumu town. Godwin hopes that if his loan request of Kshs.30000 is responded to, he will be able to uplift his business and achieve his life dream of setting up residential and rental houses and also to afford a quality education for his children. He is married and the happy father of three children.

loans.use: To boost business

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en: Celsa A. is 41 years old and is married. She lives in Barangay Bog-ot, Argao, Cebu and supports her family by operating a food-vending business. Celsa has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food-vending business. She is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Celsa is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can diversify her business and have more stock to sell. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Celsa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, sorghum, millet, beans and rice at the market, and is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour and more bags of beans and rice to sell. Rose is 41 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family and open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize flour and more bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is a 34 year old business lady who runs a chemists (pharmacy) with two employees.  She is married with a ten-year-old child.  She left her previous job where she was working as a school nurse and started her business in 2007.

In her pharmacy, she also sells mobile phone airtime cards and beauty products. She has managed to learn about customer care and good business foundation through Faulu Kenya. She hopes to move her business into the town centre in the future.

She has requested 50,000 KES to buy mobile phone airtime cards, more chemists products such as medicine and disinfectants and beauty products.  She describes herself as a hardworking and visionary lady

loans.use: To buy mobile phone airtime cards, more chemist products such as medicine and disinfectants and beauty products

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia is part of the communal bank “21 of May – El Roble” and resides in the city of Lota.  For the past seven years She has been running a grocery store in the backyard of her house with its own curb entrance. She and her husband take turns tending the business, as they open the business seven days a week, even on holidays or during festivities. She plans to purchase more merchandise with this loan. She is the mother of two, all grown up but they still reside at home even though they are economically independent. 

Silvia and her husband plan to purchase a truck, with the objective of traveling to Concepción (near Lota city) to purchase merchandise from there, as it is cheaper.  They travel to this city every month. 

Silvia has worked with the Kiva partner, Fondo Esperanza, for the past four years and is grateful for the loans she’s received that have enabled her to maintain her business. 

In Mapudungun (the language of the indigenous Mapuche population), Lota means ¨Humble Village¨.  It is a coastal community located near the city of Concepción in the southern region of Bíobío.  Lota is known for its large coal deposits, which were very important in the history and development of Chile.  The Chilean writer, Baldomero Lillo, memorializes Lota and the difficult living conditions of its coal miners in his book "Subterra" (Underground).

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise (non-perishable goods)

loans.name: Marife's Group

texts.en:
Marife E. is from the village of Gango, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. Marife is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marife E.’s Group.

To make a living, Marife owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marife has been engaged in her business for more than fifteen years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marife joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marife has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marife is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third taken out by Marife from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

About Group Loans 

In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or default.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Marbelita

texts.en:
Marbelita is a member of the communal bank "Active Women II," located in the district of Juliaca in the provinces of San Román and Puno. She is 28 years old, in a common-law marriage, and has one child. She completed her primary education. 

Marbelita has worked with Manuela Ramos for six months. Her first loan was for the amount of 500 Peru Nuevos Soles (PEN) and she used it to increase the capital in her business of selling domestic animals.

She is now asking for a loan of 800 PEN, money that will be used towards her business of selling domestic animals. 

Her dream is to have a grocery store. 

The things she enjoys most about working with the communal bank are the training sessions and the participation.

loans.use: Invest in her business selling domestic animals

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa es una madre D. familia D. 58 años D. edad que resiD. junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el sector Macuaco del distrito agrícola D. Oyotún, una zona situada a casi dos horas D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo.

Se dedica desD. hace más D. diez años a la crianza y venta D. animales menores. Ella cría aniomales menores en su domicilio y cuando estos ya han alcanzado un buen nivel D. desarrollo los ofrece en venta a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona en donD. vive. Los ingresos que percibe D. esta actiovidad le sirven para ayudar a su esposo con el sostenimiento D. la economia familiar.

Teresa desea mejorar su negocio adquiriendo más animales y alimento balanceado D. modo que pueda ampliar sus ventas y percibir mejores ingresos, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 500 nuevos soles.

Teresa es una mujer con muchas ganas D. progresar y salir adelante, su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria para mejorar su calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
Teresa is 58 years old and lives with her husband and children in the Macuaco neighborhood in the agricultural district of Oyotún, an area located about two hours from the city of Chiclayo.  

For more than 10 years, she has raised and sold small animals.  She raises small animals in her home and when they have reached a good level of development, she offers them for sale to merchants who visit the area where she lives.  The income she makes from this activity helps her husband with the family finances.

Teresa would like to improve her business by acquiring more animals and balanced feed for them so that she can increase her sales and make a larger profit.  She has asked for a loan of 500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternative to do so.

Teresa is a woman eager to make progress and get ahead.  Her dream is to continue growing as a businesswoman in order to improve her quality of life.

loans.use: Purchase animals and balanced feed

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile is 45 years old and is married with four children between the ages 7 and 15 years old.  Her husband works to  in the same medical clinic. She is a nurse and she provides medical services to the people from her area.  She employs two other nurses in her small dispensary who work in shifts to cover the full 24 hours.

Cecile would like to expand her small dispensary by adding two rooms so that she may cater to a larger number of clients. Apart from adding those two rooms, she will also try to up-grade the existing rooms by painting them.

For this reason, Cecile has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  If successful, she hopes to provide better service to her clients and, hopefully, her profits will increase.  She will continue taking care of her children by providing more food for them as well as building a secure future for them.

loans.use: To add two more rooms and renovate the existing ones

loans.name: Flordemie

texts.en:
Flordemie D. is from the village of Tigbao. She is 26 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Flordemie owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Flordemie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP per month from these activities.
     
In 2010, Flordemie joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Flordemie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben A. is from the village of Brgy. Paungan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 28 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Ruben owns & operates a motorcycle transportation business. He has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ruben joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair his vehicle to improve his service. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support his immediate family members.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle

loans.name: Florentina

texts.es:
La señora Florentina Mejía C. vive en la localidad de Amilcingo municipio de Temoac,  Morelos, México. Ella tiene 85 años de edad, ella no estudio,   Su préstamo lo va a utilizar principalmente para invertir en una plantación de cacahuate y maíz que tiene en los campos de cultivo de la localidad, también piensa pagar el trabajo de 2 peones que tiene a su servicio. Además para comprar alimento para 4 puerquitos que esta engordando. Ella lleva 11 años  dedicándose a la agricultura y menciona que los préstamos de KIVA y Fundación Realidad le han servido de mucho sobre todo para incrementar sus actividades, pues nos menciona que antes solo se dedicaba al cultivo junto con su esposo, pero ha ido aumentando su trabajo y ahora ya hasta contrata peones para que le ayuden. Antes se dedicaba a vender en las ferias dulces tradicionales en las ferias o en las plazas de Ozumba y Tétela del Volcán palanquetas, alegrías dulce de tamarindo, pero como ahora ya esta grande prefiere no salir de su localidad.
El terreno en el que actualmente vive y en que tiene sus cultivos es herencia de su esposo Normalmente se traslada en la camioneta de su propiedad hasta sus cultivos y en ocasiones también utiliza su medio de transporte para surtir de mercancía de negocio. Sus nietos son los que le ayudan a trabajar en el campo y ella personal mente alimenta a sus cerdos. Ella nos comenta que a sus familiares les gusta su negocio y le ayudan mucho en sus labores. Para ella es muy importante su trabajo porque de este se mantienen ella y sus familiares y además porque contribuyen con su trabajo al mantenimiento de la actividad del campo en su localidad. Le gusta sembrar y ver como sus siembre crece y da frutos y que siempre tiene algún producto en su casa como cacahuate, maíz o alegría.
Sus clientes son mayoristas que en la temporada de cosecha le compran su producción completa para semilla y también conserva algunos costales para vender en la localidad a sus vecinos. Sus ganancias las invierte nuevamente en sus cultivos comprando abono, o para pagar los barbechos de las tierras de labranza. Sus planes a futuro son comprar dos predios mas para la siguiente temporada de siembra y meter sorgo. Algunos de los arreglos que ha hecho en su casa son ampliar la cocina, meter agua potable en su casa.
La señora Florentina es viuda, tiene dos hijas Aurora y Ángela ambas viven con ella y participan de las actividades del campo con su mamá. También viven con ella sus nietos y todos participan de las labores del campo. Nos menciona que gracias a los préstamos de KIVA y Fundación Realidad ha podido mejorar su calidad de vida y la de sus familiares y se siente contenta de recibir nuevamente el préstamo para adquirir más tierras y seguir trabajando como hasta ahora. Nos comenta que le gusta su comunidad porque aun se conservan costumbres de sus antepasados y es tranquilo.  Sus palabras de agradecimiento para el equipo de KIVA  son las siguientes: “nos da gusto que los préstamos lleguen a las personas que los necesitan y que nos sigan apoyando con los préstamos”.
texts.en:
Florentina Mejía C. lives in the Amilcingo municipality, in Temoac in the state of Morelos, Mexico.  She is 85 years old, and she did not go to school.  She will use the loan primarily to invest in the peanuts and corn that she has planted in the area’s fields.  She also plans to pay the workers that she has at her service.  Also, she will buy food for four piglets that she is fattening.

She has been farming for 11 years, and she says that the loan from Kiva and the Fundación Realidad have greatly helped her; it especially helped increase her business activities.  She tells us that she previously only worked with crops together with her husband.  But, her work has been increasing, and now she even contracts workers to help her.

She used to sell traditional sweets at the fairs or in the Ozumba and Tétela del Vulcan plazas.  She sold “palanquetas” (similar to peanut brittle), amaranth candy, and tamarind candy.  However, now that she is elderly she prefers not to leave her area.

The land where she currently lives and has her crops is an inheritance from her husband.  Normally she goes in her own van to the crops.  Sometimes she also uses this form of transportation to stock her business with merchandise.  Her grandchildren are the ones who help her work in the field.  She personally feeds her pigs.  She tells us that her family likes her business and helps her a lot with the work.

Her work is very important to her because that is how she supports herself and her family.  It is also important because her work contributes to the maintenance of the fields in her area.  She likes to plant and to see how her plants grow and give fruit.  She always has some product in her house like peanuts, corn, or amaranth.

Her customers are wholesalers who at harvest time buy her complete production for seed.  She also saves some sacks to sell to her neighbors in the area.  She reinvests her earnings in her crops by purchasing fertilizer or paying to prepare the fields.  Her future plans are to buy two more pieces of land for the next planting season and to introduce sorghum.  Some of the repairs that she has made to her house are expanding the kitchen and putting potable water in her house.

Forentina is a widow.  She has two daughters, Aurora and Ángela.  They both live with her and participate in the field work with their mother.  Her grandchildren also live with her, and everyone participates in the field work.  She tells us that thanks to the loans from Kiva and the Fundación Realidad she has been able to improve her quality of life and that of her family.  She is happy to again receive a loan to get more land to keep working as she has been.  She tells us that she likes her community because they still follow the customs of their ancestors, and it is peaceful.

Her words of gratitude to the Kiva team are the following, “It gives us pleasure that the loans go to the people that need them, and they continue supporting us with the loans”.

loans.use: To buy fumigants, pay the workers, and for raising pigs

loans.name: Ma. Theresa

texts.en:
Ma. Theresa I. is from the village of Poblacion, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 54 years old. Ma. Theresa is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Theresa owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods, beverages & toothpaste in the local community. Ma. Theresa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ma. Theresa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Theresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Ma. Theresa is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk foods. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ma. Theresa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. This picture was taken during the center meeting with other clients. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods & junk foods.

loans.name: Naimodu Enole

texts.en:
Naimodu Enole N. is 40 years old. She is a single mother blessed with five children. She has been farming on her own piece of land for the last seven years now. Naimodu's dream is to educate her children to university level and expand her farming activity. 

Naimodu first learned about KADET from other women in a group already registered with KADET where she lives. This will be her third loan. She paid her previous loans well and on time. She plans to spend the entire amount on farm inputs. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you the members of the “Unity” group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to the SMT/Kiva lenders to ask for a loan of 500,000 SLL each in order to invest in their businesses. 

Fatmata B. is the leader of this group. She is 23 years old and married with two children. She sells rice, and has been a businesswoman for fifteen good years. With the help of this loan, Fatmata will invest in her business by buying more bags of rice to resell.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice to resell

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 51 years old and is married, with three children who are between 6 and 20 years old. Martin takes care of one dependent who is a 20 year-old relative. He and his wife work hard for the development of their family. 

Martin owns a business selling cassava.  His business is well-known, as well as organized. He employs three people as helpers so that his business runs smoothly. Martin has four years experience in his business.  The hours of his business are from 6am until 9pm every day.

Martin has requested his first loan from KIva lenders, via Vision Finance Company, in order to purchase more cassava.  That will help him to satisfy his many customers of cassava.  Martin will then be able to earn more profits to be reinvested in his business, and will save money for his future.

loans.use: To purchase more large quanties of cassava.

loans.name: Ana Dilma

texts.es: Ana Dilma G. M. de cuarenta y cinco años de edad,madre soltera vive con su hija en casa propia ubicada en Tonacatepeque departamento de San Salvador. Ella posee un negocio en su vivienda donde vende ropa, sandalias y por las noches vende pupusas, Ana Dilma es toda una mujer llena de ideales dispuesta a trabajar duro para subsistir; es por eso que le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita  comprar más productos como blusas, pantalones, faldas y sandalias pues últimamente tiene más clientela y quiere satisfacer sus necesidades. Ana quiere un mejor futuro para su hija Ingrid y tiene fe que así mejorara la calidad de vida de ambas.
texts.en:
Ana Dilma G. M. is 45 years old.  She is a single mother and lives with her daughter in her own home which is located in Tonacatepeque, in San Salvador department.  Ana has a business in her home where she sells clothes and sandals.  In the evenings, she sells pupusas (thick corn tortillas filled with cheese, meat or beans).

Ana is a woman who is full of ideals and who is prepared to work hard in order to survive.  She is requesting a loan from INTEGRAL which will allow her to buy more products such as blouses, pants, skirts and sandals as she has had more customers recently and she would like to be able to meet their needs.  Ana wants a better future for her daughter Ingrid and she believes that, in this way, she will improve both Ingrid's and her own quality of life.

loans.use: to buy blouses, pants, skirts and sandals

loans.name: Nuevo Progreso 1 Group

texts.en:
Felicia is the coordinator of her group Nuevo Progreso (New Progress) 1 and her story is representative of the other members of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally.

Felicia´s group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo, they live in the north of the main city, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home in a simple structure with her husband and they have six grown children. Her most difficult challenge was to have her own little home and she wants to live tranquil and safe in it. She enjoys to do her favorite activity 'business'.

Felicia is excited to be taking out her sixth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a colmado, or small general store, by stocking rice, beans, cooking oil, spaghetti, sauces, canned products and flour. She will use the profits to re-invest in her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, cooking oil, sugar and flour

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay C. is a 45-year-old farmer who lives in Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham province. She is married to Hout Chea, age 47. This couple, pictured above, works together in the farming business.  They have four children: three of the children are single and one is married.

Lay C. raises piglets and she had hoped to sell them to buyers four months after she began raising them. Unfortunately, the pigs are not big enough, due to the lack of food. To help solve this problem, Lay C. has requested a loan that she will use to buy sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs.

loans.use: to buy sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs.

loans.name: Josephine
